answers.author: Amanda Dodge
answers.text:
Hi Lauren, 
I have been able to find a few examples of citizen satisfaction surveys that will hopefully help answer your question. I am unfamiliar with Pacific Local Governments, but hopefully these will be useful templates.
These two surveys are just the questions, without the answers or analysis:
2004 City of Clearwater, Florida Citizen Satisfaction Survey: http://bit.ly/gwqQSj
2003 City of Greenwood Village, Colorado Citizen Satisfaction Survey: http://bit.ly/hFN51d
Additionally, ICMA and The National Research center collaborate to provide a service to local governments by creating somthing called the National Citizen Survey. To get more information on their services you can go to: http://icma.org/en/results/surveying/national_citizen_survey
An example of one of the cities they surveyed was Dover, Delaware. In the report there is more of an analysis of the information received from the survey. Moreover, towards the bottom of the report the percentage of answers for each question are listed along with various graphs:
http://bit.ly/engaxQ
I hope this helps!
Amanda Dodge
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
202-962-3699
adodge@icma.org

answers.author: Craig Rapp
answers.text:
I agree with Amanda. The National Citizen's Survey is a valuable tool - it has been used by many jurisdictions across the country, which enables the folks at the  National Research Center to provide a unique national perspective to their clients along with the local results. They are an experienced, knowledgeable organization.  A group in the Minneapolis area, Decision Resources, Ltd. has conducted surveys for cities, counties and school districts for over twenty-five years in that region and they would have similar experience to the National Research folks. but on a local level: 
http://www.drl-mpls.com/Contact.html
Craig Rapp

author: Lauren Oakey
text:
Can anyone provide and examples of questions that you would ask in your local council to gather data on 'Community Satisfaction Surveys' and something that might be useful in Pacific Local Governments?
These would be questions targeted at gathering information on - measuring performance, effectiveness and efficiency of council service delivery, leadership and governance, for example.
title: Council Monitoring & Evaluation Strategies
